TopicTitle: What kinds of missions to you wish KSP supported?

Articles.Content:
Say KSP had like every feature needed to do it, what missions do you wish you could send out.

The one I'd really like to send out would be an Europa ocean mission, in this case I'm guessing Eeloo, Minimus, or some Europa analog that doesn't exist now, set up an orbiter relay station, then a lander with a nuclear heated drill, which drops a sub that explores the ocean below the ice.

So that would mean, we'd need a Eurpoa analog, we'd need terrain deformation, a drill that deforms terrain, and submarine physics.

Please note, we're not asking the Dev's for anything in this thread, just like what are your crazy things you'd like to do if KSP could support it.
Wouldn't Vall count as a Europa analog?

Wouldn't Vall count as a Europa analog?

I know right?
Sample return missions. I would love for some for some manned and unmanned ways of bring back rocks and gasses, and then you could show them off in your trophy room in the VAB

oh, I wonder how we can do a sample return mission? I know, look below at my signature

Capture an Asteroid into Munar Orbit.

Wouldn't Vall count as a Europa analog?

OMG I can't believe I didn't think about Vall, I'm such a dummy.

Ok, so I wanna drill thru Vall and search under the ice.
I just want Kerbs to be able to like add fuel hoses and struts while in space.... that would be much more useful than planing flags.
Stuff that requires two active pilots, like White Knight/SpaceShipOne. As it is, one of them is going to crash.
Super realistic shaders would be awesome. Lens glare, lights causing dark things around them to be faded out, etc.
Comet intercept mission Either kerballed mission with a lander, sample gathering etc, or just slamming an impactor at about 12 km/s of relative velocity. Now that would leave a crater worth seeing
Kerbals pass out if there is more than a certain amount of G-force. Then you would be really screwed.

Actual science missions would be really cool; you could send out probes that had a purpose, rather than simply sticking Gravioli Detector on the side and observing that the gravity on Dres is x m/s^2. Sample return would be cool too, or colonization--you could set up permanent colonies on other worlds!

Science missions

- measurements

- sample return

- R&D in micro gravity

Payload delivery

- for government

- private sector

Mining

- rare materials

Sample return missions. I would love for some for some manned and unmanned ways of bring back rocks and gasses, and then you could show them off in your trophy room in the VAB

Definitely.

At the moment, there is absolutely no reason for me to send Kerbals home, so they keep accumulating in bases and stations throughout the solar system. Anything that would give a good reason to go home would be a great addition.

I just want Kerbs to be able to like add fuel hoses and struts while in space.... that would be much more useful than planing flags.

Kerbal Attatchment System does hoses and I thought the Strut Gun and/or Quantum Struts can be turned on and off in space.
Life support systems would be cool and force players to bring Kerbals back. They could also fix co2 scrubbers and other parts, not just wheels. They being Kerbals
Repairing space stations using duct tape.
I think that when career mode comes out they could add some sort of tourism profit. Kind of like deliver kerbals to orbit or bring them too mun hotels/stations for profit.

Maybe some sort of 'Space Race', where you compete with the computer (KSC 2?) to launch missions and achieve certain milestones? Or the other space centre could just launch missions every so often to accomplish their own things.
Carryable hand tools like fuel lines they can run to other ships, carryable drill that can hold say, 15 L of kethane. And so on.
Movable and retractable docking ring arms for refueling and docking in tight spots.

The ability for kerbals to run hoses in the stock game would be excellent.

The ability of kerbals to add struts during EVAs would be excellent. Or the ability to mount telescoping struts to a ship that could extend and latch onto whatever they hit would be OK...but that would require more planning ahead of time, whereas a kerbal being able to strut any point A to point B would be more versatile.

Requiring that a "hose pack" or "strut pack" be attached to the ship before a kerbal could do this would be acceptably realistic.

Aside from the ability to add things like struts, etc. what about the Kerbals on EVA getting equipped with a hammer, to knock off parts that are deemed useless, because somehow during the flight, the ships's configuration or mission requirements have changed, or to balance out engines.
